results.title: Uf-oh
results.creator_credit: John Bird, Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School and Glenn Melenhorst
results.brief_description: Adrian (voice by Egan Gill) is quietly working on his computer, but his trusty companion, a bandicoot named Openhiemer (voice by Paul Gherig), has other plans. Openheimer meddles with the computers and taps into some alien life, causing all sorts of mischief.

results.title: Udder butter
results.creator_credit: D. Keith Carlson and WGBH Educational Foundation
results.brief_description: The origin of milk and the intricacies of a milking machine provide the subject for discussion amongst a group of children. Observing a live calf is an integrated activity.

results.title: Udaipur, city of lakes
results.creator_credit: Ezra Mir, Films Division, Government of India and P.R.S. Pillay
results.brief_description: This beautiful lakeside city of India attracts tourists from all over the world. Udaipur is a city of palaces, surrounded by hills and lakes essential for irrigation which also enhance the landscape. Wonderful gardens, temples decorated with carved marble and a tower of victory built in the 15th century are examples of the beauty of this city. These religious people love festivals; with a boat procession on the lake and girls wearing colorful saris.

results.title: Ubu Roi Ou les Polonais
results.brief_description:
Alfred Jarry’s Ubu roi (‘King Ubu’) was produced in 1896, with nonrealistic settings and costumes. All the scene settings were displayed simultaneously on a backdrop, and the costumes and makeup were deliberately grotesque, as was the acting style, an amalgam of buffoonery, the horror of Grand Guignol, and extravagant mock-tragedy. Far from posing an alternative to the materialist values of the bourgeois audience, the first line of Ubu roi attacked the audience’s values head on. When Firmin Gemier, in the title role, advanced to face the audience, looked directly into their eyes, and uttered the first scandalous word of the text, ‘merde’ (‘excrement’), a pattern was set that has been followed by many avant-garde theatre companies throughout the 20th century. Reference: Encyclopedia Britanica Online. http://members.eb.com/bol/topic?eu=118827&sctn=3. Accessed January 3 2000

Credits: Director, Jean-Christophe Averty ; photography, Lucien Billard ; music, Claude Terrasse.
Cast: Jean Bouise, Rosy Varte, Hubert Deschamps, Henri Virlojeux.

results.title: Ubu Films: 1965-1970
results.creator_credit: Ubu Films, David Perry, Albie Thoms, Aggy Read and Clemency Weight
results.brief_description: A compilation of experimental shorts made by members of Australia’s first consciously avant garde filmmaking group formed in Sydney in 1965. ‘Blunderball’ (Albie Thoms, 1966), is a parody of James Bond films; in ‘Man and His World’ (Albie Thoms, 1966) a one second image is stretched to fifty seconds; ‘Puncture’ (David Perry, 1967) was created by punching holes in opaque filmstock; ‘Halftone’ (David Perry, 1966) explores the abstract graphic potential of newspaper photographs; ‘Rita & Dundi’ (Albie Thoms, 1966) is a portrait of two women in inner city Sydney; records a ‘happening’ on four cameras; ‘Bluto’ (Albie Thoms, 1967) is a hand-made scratch film; ‘The Tribulations of Mr Dupont Nomore’ (David Perry, 1967) concerns the escape fantasies of a henpecked husband; in ‘Transition’ (Aggy Read,1967) a blank screen is filled with random lines and shapes; ‘Super Block High’ (Aggy Read,1967) is a hand made film created by incising opaque film stock with a grinding wheel; ‘Moon Virility’ (Albie Thoms, 1967) is a hand-made film with a ‘found’ optical soundtrack; ‘Bolero’ (Albie Thoms, 1967) is a n experiment in visual perception to Ravel’s music; ‘Boobs a Lot’ (Aggy Read, 1968) is a montage of Playboy centrefolds cut to the music of the Fugs; ‘David Perry’ (Albie Thoms, 1968) is a ‘synthetic documentary’ of the artist; ‘Tobias Icarus Age Four’ (Clem Weight, 1968); ‘A Sketch on Abigayl’s Belly’ (David Perry, 1968) is a ‘poetic diary film of Perry’s wife’s pregnancy ; ‘Marinetti’ (Albie Thoms, 1969) is a complex ‘longform’ film inspired by F.T. Marinetti; ‘Infinity Girl’ (Aggy Read, 1969) is a film poem with multiple superimpositions; ‘Album’ (David Perry, 1970) is a montage on the theme of the film-maker’s family album.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ubu Films, David Perry, Albie Thoms, Aggy Read and Clemency Weight

Marinetti; ‘Infinity Girl’ (Aggy Read, 1969) is a film poem with multiple superimpositions; ‘Album’ (David Perry, 1970) is a montage on the theme of the film-maker’s family album.

results.title: Ubu
results.creator_credit: Grand Slamm Animation, Arts Council of Great Britain and Geoff Dunbar
results.brief_description: Ubu Roi was written by Alfred Jarry as a schoolboy in 1888. It’s first public performance was in 1896 and it immediately gained the notoriety that it continues to enjoy. The bare bones of the story are those of ‘Macbeth’. For this animated version, Geoff Dunbar has invented a brutal graphic style and ‘language’ of sounds to re-create the explosive impact of Jerry’s original production. Animated by Geoff Dunbar, Annabel Jankel, Ian Lewis, Ginger Gibbons and assisted by Tony Barnes and Gail Wright. Based on the play ‘Ubu Roi’ by Alfred Jarry.

results.title: U.N. Kindergarten
results.brief_description: Deals with the kindergarten set up to cater for the children of United Nations officials in New York. Children of 25 nationalities work and play together amicably as a practical example of international cooperation.

results.title: U.N. in the classroom
results.creator_credit: Julian Biggs, ONF | NFB and Don Haldane
results.brief_description: With minimum supervision from their teacher, seventh-grade school children conduct a model classroom assembly, patterned after a session of the United Nations, and debate an issue. The film demonstrates an original approach in helping children get to know the world they live in.
